title: "Role With It" Cards
lessonRelevance: Part of a fun simulated data collection activity. Students "introduce" both sexes of a set of species (by vocalizing and dancing) and build a data table.

title: Borneo Atmospheric Video
description: This video sets the ambience for the beginning of Part 3 of our "Guardian Frogs" lesson. It situates students in the geographic location, sights, and sounds, and a sense of mystery regarding the island of Borneo.
lessonRelevance: For Part 3: An atmospheric video plays as students enter the classroom, immediately immersing them in the lesson's sights, sounds, geographic location, and sense of mystery.

title: Do Female Frogs Call?
description: Dr. Johana Goyes-Vallejos discovers that in the smooth guardian frog of Borneo, female frogs call. In frog species, typically male frogs call, while females stay silent. Dr. Johana Goyes-Vallejos shows that in the smooth guardian frog of Borneo (Limnonectes palavanensis) this is not the case and that female frogs call, too, producing spontaneous vocalizations to attract males. Dr. Goyes-Vallejosâ€™ discovery that female frogs call suggests that L. palavanensis exhibits a reversal in calling behavior and possibly a sex-role-reversed mating system, which would be the first ever observed in a frog species.
lessonRelevance: For Part 3: We show parts of this video to introduce students to Dr. Goyes-Vallejos and her research. They will then analyze some of her data.

title: Calling behavior of male and female Guardian Frogs
description: Electronic Supplementary Material: Calling behavior of males and females of a Bornean frog with male parental care and possible sex-role reversal (Goyes Vallejos, J., Ulmar Grafe, T., Ahmad Sah, H.H. et al. Behav Ecol Sociobiol. 2017. 71: 95).
lessonRelevance: For Part 3: Background video showing that male and female Guardian Frogs look similar, but have a distinct call.
